subject: Design
subcategory: Design Disasters and What They Teach Us
title: Gap's Logo Disaster: When Crowds Kill Creativity
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Gap's Logo Disaster: When Crowds Kill Creativity.

hook.text: In 2010, Gap revealed a new logo. The internet revolted so fiercely that Gap reversed the change in six days.

buildup.text: The classic blue box with serif 'GAP' was replaced by a Helvetica wordmark with a tiny blue gradient square.

discovery.text: Thousands of parodies appeared online. 'Make your own Gap logo' generators went viral. It became a global joke.

twist.text: Gap's crowd-sourcing attempt â€” asking the internet to submit better logos â€” made things even worse.

climax.text: The Gap fiasco proved that brand equity lives in the audience, not the company. You can't redesign love.

punchline.text: The shortest-lived logo in corporate history lasted exactly six days.

quiz.question: Why did Gap reverse its logo change after only six days?
options: Massive public backlash and online mockery
